title: President Trump Approves Texas Disaster Declaration Related to COVID-19 Pandemic
summary:
President Donald Trump declared a major disaster exists in Texas related to the outbreak of novel coronavirus and ordered Federal assistance be sent to the Lone Star State.
“Texas is aggressively pursuing and implementing all necessary strategies to limit the impact of COVID-19, and I thank President Trump for his swift action to issue a Major Disaster Declaration for the State of Texas,” said Abbott in a statement Wednesday.
Additional federal funding is essential for us to maintain our aggressive course of action to protect our state."
Trump's action makes Federal funding available for crisis counseling, an area Abbott specifically requested assistance for, for affected individuals in all areas of Texas.
Federal funding is also available to state and eligible local governments and certain private nonprofit organizations for emergency protective measures, including direct Federal assistance, for all areas in the State of Texas impacted by COVID-19.

title: Fort Worth Stock Show & Rodeo Through the Years
summary:
As the Rodeo portion of the Fort Worth Stock Show and Rodeo moves into a new home at Dickies Arena NBC 5 wanted to take a look back at the legendary event.
For almost 125 years, the Fort Worth Stock Show has been a part of the fabric of North Texas.
Here is a list of some of the most notable dates in Stock Show history:1896: The first Stock Show takes place in March in North Fort Worth.
-- The second show, held October 12-13 to coincide with the National Livestock Exchange-- Convention meeting featured the first parade1901: Officially adopts the name Texas Fat Stock Show1907: Admission charged for the first time: 25 cents1910: First automobile exhibit debuts at the Stock Show1911: Former president, Theodore Roosevelt is the guest of honor1916: Miller Brothers 101 Ranch Wild West Show featured "the first cowgirl" as deemed by Will Rogers1918: Stock Show adopts Southwestern Exposition and Fat Stock Show as the official name1927: Bareback Bronco riding added to rodeo events1932: First live radio broadcast of a rodeo [NBC through Amon Carter's Fort Worth affiliate WBAP (We Bring A Program)]1943: Stock Show canceled due to World War II1944: Stock Show moves to Will Rogers Memorial Center-- Gene Autry becomes the first entertainer to appear at a rodeo1946: 50th Anniversary of the Stock Show1958: Fort Worth Rodeo is the first to receive complete live national television coverage1984: Amon G. Carter Jr. Exhibits hall opens1987: The Stock Show adopts Southwestern Exposition and Livestock Show as the official name1996: Stock Show celebrates its centennial2002: Stock Show expands to 23 days with record-breaking 951,000 visitors2008: Fort Worth Stock Show and Rodeo inducted into Pro Rodeo Hall of Fame2011: 25th Anniversary of Fort Worth Calf Scramble2020: Rodeo events move to Fort Worth's new Dickies Arena

title: 2 men found dead inside vehicle pulled from Trinity River early Friday
summary:
Two people were found dead after crews pulled a vehicle from the Trinity River in Fort Worth early Friday, said Mike Drivdahl, a spokesman for the Fort Worth fire department.
Fort Worth firefighters responded to a 911 call of a possible vehicle submerged in the river in the 400 block of North University Drive around 2:30 a.m. Friday, Drivdahl said.
They found a truck submerged in the river, where water was about 10 feet deep, Drivdahl said.
Happening Now: The crash In Fort Worth where a truck was recovered after plunging off the University dr bridge and falling into the Trinity River is now a double fatality.
Temperatures in Fort Worth were in the upper 40s early Friday morning around the time of the incident, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth tops the country in office job growth
summary:

D-FW also outpaced Houston and Charlotte, N.C., two other fast-growing economies, in year-over-year office job gains.
Dallas led the country in job growth last year, with 5.7% year-over-year growth in office jobs.
Texas has three of the top five job growth markets in the country, and Austin tops the list with projected job growth of 2.6% in 2020.
It found that job growth in tech markets continues to defy high costs and tight labor supplies.

title: Teen Girl Killed in Outbreak of Shootings in Fort Worth
summary:

The victim was transported to the hospital with injuries that police said were serious but not life-threatening.
Minutes later, police also responded to a shooting at a house in the 7800 block of Novella Drive in South Fort Worth.

title: Crews Now Working Weekends on 3 Bridges Near Downtown Fort Worth
summary:

Man Fatally Shoots Son During Dispute, Police Say
summary:

Officers were called to a home in the 300 block of Coach House Circle, south of White Settlement Road and west of W. Loop 820, at about 12:30 p.m., police said.
The 24-year-old was taken to a local hospital, where he died from his injuries, police said.

title: Martial Law Isn’t ‘Imminent’
summary:
The following day, Defense Secretary Mark Esper clarified: “To be clear, this is not a move toward martial law, as some have erroneously claimed.”Esper was responding to persistent online rumors that martial law is either currently in place or very near.
Andrew Cuomo also has said he won’t institute martial law, and the Washington National Guard issued a statement on Twitter saying, “Let’s put aside the rumors about martial law or military rule.
This is a humanitarian mission to support health and safety.”So, martial law isn’t in effect and it’s not imminent.
But that’s the opposite of martial law, which exists only if there is no civil law.
“As long as civil function continues,” Corn said, the courts will find “invocation of martial law is unconstitutional.”The other experts we talked to agreed that national-scale martial law is exceedingly unlikely.

Renoir: The Body, The Senses is the first major exhibition ever to focus on the artist's lifelong treatment of the nude.
Featuring approximately 60 paintings, drawings, pastels and sculptures by Renoir as well as works by his predecessors, contemporaries and followers, the exhibition's roster is exceptional.
This exhibition redefines Renoir as a brilliant, radical and influential artist of the modern age, reconsidering him as a constantly evolving artist who participated in myriad movements, including Realism, Impressionism and Modernism.

title: Austin leads major Texas cities with largest traffic decrease during stay-at-home order
summary:
AUSTIN, Texas — According to data from the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT), Austin has seen the largest decrease in traffic of any major city during the statewide stay-at-home order.
The data compares weekly traffic in select TxDOT districts to traffic from their baseline week of Feb. 22 to Feb. 28, before the order was put in place.
That same week, San Antonio traffic decreased by 43% and Fort Worth saw a 42% decrease.
Dallas and Houston saw the least significant traffic decrease that week with 37% and 39%, respectively.
On a statewide basis, weekly traffic totals have shifted from an 18% decrease the week March 14 to March 20 to a 41% decrease the week of March 28 to April 3.

title: What a near-record strength polar vortex means for weather in Dallas-Fort Worth
summary:
What is the polar vortex and what could its strength mean Dallas-Fort Worth’s weather?
That’s because of another weather feature called Arctic Oscillation, a weather pattern that affects much of the Northern Hemisphere.
Positive Arctic Oscillation essentially keeps the polar vortex in check and confined to the Arctic Circle.
So while the polar vortex is at near-record strength, Arctic Oscillation’s record strength should keep the polar vortex in check and prevent it from slipping south, according to Matthew Cappucci, a meteorologist for the Capital Weather Gang of The Washington Post.
That means the chances of a strong arctic outbreak reaching Dallas-Fort Worth is unlikely for the foreseeable future.

title: Treasury Secretary warns US could see 20% unemployment rate due to coronavirus, source says
summary:
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin warned Republican senators Tuesday that the coronavirus pandemic could drive up US unemployment to 20%, a Republican Senate source told CNN.
Mnuchin's comments came as he urged Republican senators to act on economic stimulus measures totaling $1 trillion designed to avert that kind of worst case scenario.
In the same meeting, Mnuchin also said he is concerned the economic ramifications of the coronavirus pandemic could be worse than the 2008 financial crisis, the source said.
Mnuchin's comments, which were first reported by Bloomberg News, come amid a rising sense of urgency at the White House and on Capitol Hill to confront the increasingly serious threat of the coronavirus pandemic — on both the public health and economic fronts.

title: Has Dallas-Fort Worth seen its last freeze of the season?
summary:
Lows in the 30s aren’t in the forecast for Dallas-Fort Worth in the near future, and, historically, the average date of the last freeze — March 12 — is near.
On average, Dallas-Fort Worth gets about two freezes in the month of March.
Dallas-Fort Worth has recorded a freeze as late into the year as April 13, which has happened in 1997 and 1957, according to the National Weather Service.
Last year, Dallas-Fort Worth got its last freeze of the season on March 6, according to the weather service.
So, I think our chance for another freeze is very low.”In 2017, Dallas-Fort Worth recorded the earliest last freeze of the season on Jan. 8, when the temperature dropped to 20 degrees.

title: Coronavirus concern, price war drives Texas gas prices to lowest level in more than a year
summary:
Gas prices across Texas are reaching lows not seen in more than a year as concerns about the coronavirus impact coupled with price wars between top producers have caused crude oil prices to plummet.
“Texas gas prices are at their cheapest point in more than a year,” AAA Texas spokesperson Joshua Zuber said in a statement Thursday.
The average gas price in Texas is $2.01 per gallon, even lower than the national average of $2.32 per gallon, according to AAA.
If crude oil prices remain at current levels, AAA predicts drivers will continue to see low prices at the pump.
The lowest gas prices in the Dallas-Fort Worth metro Thursday morning were at Love’s, Brookshire’s and Valero in Bridgeport, where gas is $1.65 per gallon, according to GasBuddy.com.

summary:
Dallas County Judge Clay Jenkins, Tarrant County Judge Glen Whitley and Fort Worth Mayor Betsy price today have signed amended orders expanding restrictions intended to stem the spread of COVID-19.
New restrictions in Fort Worth and the rest of Tarrant County go into effect at 6 p.m. today (Saturday, March 21) and new restrictions in Dallas County go into effect at midnight tonight.
The new restrictions allow essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and other establishments that sell household goods to remain open, but requires them to enforce social separation.
In-house dining at restaurants remains closed, but drive-in, drive-through, takeout and delivery are still permitted.
Dallas County also now limits the sale of toilet paper to 12 rolls per purchase, or if the package has more than 12 rolls, you can only buy that one package.

title: FEMA rejects Texas’ disaster request over Dallas’ October tornadoes, denying region millions of dollars
summary:
The Federal Emergency Management Agency has rejected Texas’ request for a major disaster declaration – denying it millions of dollars in federal relief funding – over the destructive October tornadoes that smashed through Dallas County.
The state had estimated that the October storms caused upwards of $190 million in public infrastructure damage in Dallas County.
If FEMA had approved Abbott’s major disaster declaration request, Texas would’ve been eligible for a 75% reimbursement, meaning that the region could’ve tapped into millions of dollars – and perhaps tens of millions of dollars – from the agency’s disaster relief fund.
North Texas needed to have sustained $38.5 million in uninsured losses to public infrastructure to qualify for a disaster declaration.
Later in the month, he approved Texas’ major disaster declaration request over the outbreak, allowing federal relief dollars to start flowing toward the state and local response on that front.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth got off easy during second-hottest October worldwide
summary:
While much of the globe sweated through an abnormally warm October, Dallas-Fort Worth lucked out last month.
While much of Asia, Africa, Australia, Europe and South America saw above-average temperatures last month, one portion of North America — including Dallas-Fort Worth — saw below-average temperatures, according to NOAA.
Temperatures in Dallas-Fort Worth during October averaged slightly below normal, according to the National Weather Service.
Scientists and researchers believe that if Earth's average temperature rises by that figure by 2100, catastrophic changes could follow.
An analysis published earlier this year by The Washington Post found that while some parts of the U.S. are warming rapidly and others show signs of cooling, Dallas-Fort Worth sits somewhere in the middle.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth records its first freeze of the season
summary:
The first freeze of the season came early for Dallas-Fort Worth.
On average Dallas-Fort Worth records its first freeze of the season by Nov. 22, according to the National Weather Service.
Thursday’s freeze was the ninth earliest freeze of the season for Dallas-Fort Worth, according to the weather service.
Ahead of the front, the weather service issued a freeze warning for Dallas, Denton, Collin and Tarrant counties.
Usually the weather service issues only one freeze warning per season to alert the public about freezing temperatures, said Monique Sellers, a weather service meteorologist.

title: Dallas-Fort Worth’s construction boom ranks second nationally in 2019
summary:
Dallas-Fort Worth was the second-busiest building market in the country last year with almost $22.5 billion in construction.
Only New York City had more total construction — both residential and nonresidential — than the D-FW area, according to information from Dodge Data & Analytics.
About $10 billion of local construction starts were for nonresidential commercial projects — everything from office buildings to retail and warehouses — which rose 14% from 2018.
Residential building starts totaled about $12.6 billion, down 12% from 2018’s total, according to Dodge Data.
Houston ranked third nationally for construction starts with $18.7 billion in building.

title: Stormy cold front brings rain, plunges temps into 40s in Dallas-Fort Worth
summary:

title: Here’s why this cold front is stronger than most — and how long it will last in Dallas-Fort Worth
summary:
Shortly before 10 a.m. Monday, it was 65 degrees at DFW International Airport, according to the National Weather Service.
“It’s certainly the strongest one we’ve seen this season,” weather service meteorologist Monique Sellers said of the front.
Normally this time of the year, Dallas-Fort Worth records highs in the upper 60s and lows in the upper 40s, according to the weather service.
Dallas-Fort Worth did not break any cold records, but records were broken in hundreds of cities from the Plains to the East Coast through Wednesday, according to The Washington Post.
A strong cold front year sent Dallas-Fort Worth temperatures into the 20s about this time last year, too.

title: Arctic cold front headed for Dallas-Fort Worth will drop temperatures into the 20s
summary:
After mild weather this weekend, temperatures in Dallas-Fort Worth are expected to plunge into the 20s.
A strong cold front is forecast to move through North Texas on Monday, according to KXAS-TV (NBC5) meteorologist Grant Johnston.
Any rain is expected to end before temperatures start to drop, preventing the chance for any wintry precipitation in Dallas-Fort Worth, according to Matt Stalley, a weather service meteorologist.
Some portions of Dallas-Fort Worth could see wind chills drop into the single digits and teens by Tuesday morning, said Steve Fano, a weather service meteorologist.
With wind gusts up to 50 mph possible, the weather service issued a wind advisory for most of North Texas, including Dallas-Fort Worth.

title: 3 Charged in Deadly Fort Worth Shooting
summary:
Three people face charges in the October shooting death of a 20-year-old man in Fort Worth, police say.
Antwan Griffin-Swanson, 21; Freddie Scott, 20; and Altynesha Alexander, 20 each face charges of murder in the shooting of Jaylon Hardemon, NBC 5 learned Thursday after a review of the police incident report.
Police said he was found fatally wounded Oct. 29 in the 1700 block of East Robert Street, on Fort Worth's southeast side.
In addition to murder charges, Scott is charged with aggravated assault with a deadly weapon, and Alexander has a charge of theft of property between $100-$750, police reports show.
Alexander was arrested Nov. 26, Scott on Nov. 21 and Griffin-Swanson on Nov. 19.

title: DFW Airport will shatter passenger records in 2019, but it’s racking up more flight delays, too
summary:
When 2019 wraps up, nearly 75 million passengers will have traveled through DFW International Airport -- more than 5 million travelers than a year ago.
“This year’s growth has been the strongest we have seen in 15 to 20 years,” said Sean Donohue, CEO of DFW Airport.
If airport traffic follows the same trend from the last 15 years, that will give it a record-breaking 74.7 million total passengers in 2019, according to airport statistics.
Love Field has little growth potential because of the complicated federal Wright Amendment law that limits it to 20 gates.
DFW officials have also reached an agreement with American Airlines to build a new $3 billion Terminal F with up to 24 gates.

title: Brrrrr… North Texas Braces For Below Freezing Overnight Temperatures
summary:
NORTH TEXAS (CBSDFW.COM) – North Texas is preparing for the coldest dose of weather yet this season as an arctic front heads our way for Veterans Day.
The front brings a sharp and sudden temperature drop, gusty north winds, and a slight chance for rain followed by our first hard freeze of the season.
North winds gusting up to 40-45 mph will send wind chill values into the 20s Monday afternoon and into the teens overnight.
To account for the extreme wind, a Wind Advisory is in effect for all of North Texas Monday morning through Tuesday morning.
The cold weather will make it feel like we’re in the end of winter rather than late fall.

“First and foremost, I want to again express my complete confidence in Chief Kraus and the leadership team at the Fort Worth Police Department,” said City Manager Cooke.
They will conduct a rigorous and completely independent review of the police department, the city of Fort Worth said in a news release Friday.
It is my hope that together, we can continue to propel this positive step forward and continue to drive change for a better Fort Worth.

title: 3 Dead, 3 Injured After 18-Wheeler Explodes On I-35W Near Denton
summary:

One of the two 18-wheelers involved was carrying butane tanks, which caused an explosion.
Firefighters and police officers responded Friday afternoon to the major crash in the 2300 block of I-35W.
There were fatalities in three of the burned out cars, including the two vehicles on the big rig.
Police had to count the rims to discern how many vehicles were actually involved in the horrific crash.

title: Census: Texas Counties Saw Large Population Gains Over Past Decade
summary:
Six of the 10 U.S. counties with the largest population gains this decade were in Texas, according to the U.S. Census Bureau’s July 1, 2019, population estimates released this week.
“One interesting trend we have seen this decade is widespread population decline among smaller counties, while larger counties tended to have population growth,” Christine Hartley, a demographer in the Census Bureau’s Population Division, said.
“Three out of four counties with a population of less than 10,000 in 2010 had even smaller populations in 2019.
At the same time, three out of four counties of 50,000 or more were larger in 2019 compared to 2010.”The pattern among larger counties is particularly evident in the West and South.
Vintage 2019 is the last series of population estimates to be released before the 2020 Decennial Census is completed.

The 2020 edition of The Old Farmer's Almanac predicts a milder, drier winter than normal for portions of Texas and Oklahoma, but it's not counting out a chance for snow.
The almanac predicts the best chances for snow in Oklahoma and North Texas, including Dallas-Fort Worth, are in early December, early to mid-January and mid-February.
North Texas saw its first snowflakes of 2019 on Jan. 19.
The almanac also predicts the coldest periods of the winter will arrive in late December, late January and mid-February.

title: Lone Star Politics | December 8, 2019
North Texas home sales set record in 2019
summary:
North Texas’ housing market ended 2019 on a high note, and the jump in sales during the final month was enough to push the year’s home purchases to an all-time high.
Area real estate agents sold more than 108,000 single-family homes for the year — 3% more than in 2018, according to preliminary data from the Real Estate Center at Texas A&M University and North Texas Real Estate Information Systems.
“Dallas-Fort Worth winds up with record sales again,” said James Gaines, chief economist for the Real Estate Center.
For all of 2019, North Texas home prices were 3% ahead of those in 2018, according to the Real Estate Center.
There are indications that January will be another strong month for North Texas home purchases.

title: This is how much warmer the winter in Dallas-Fort Worth has become since 1970
summary:
For almost 50 years, average winter temperatures in Dallas-Fort Worth have been trending up, according to a new analysis.
The warming winter trend is true for most of the country.
The analysis, produced by Climate Central, found that 79% of 242 U.S. cities have recorded a rise in average winter temperatures of at least 2 degrees since 1970.
The Northeast saw the greatest rise in average winter temperatures, while portions of Northern California and the Pacific Northwest have experienced less dramatic increases, the study found.

title: D-FW warehouse leasing and construction set records in 2019
summary:
North Texas warehouse demand soared to a record level in 2019, fueled by e-commerce and consumer products company growth.
That’s up from about 23 million square feet in 2018.
Businesses moved into almost 13 million square feet of local warehouse space in the fourth quarter alone.
More than 28 million square feet of industrial buildings were under construction in the area this month — up from about 22 million a year ago.
Most of the warehouse construction is around North Fort Worth’s Alliance Airport (9.8 million square feet), near DFW Airport (5.2 million) and in the Great Southwest district (2.5 million).

title: Texas December Sales Tax Revenue Up 5% Over 2018, Comptroller Says
summary:
Texas sales tax revenue totaled $3.01 billion in December, 4.8 percent more than in December 2018, Texas Comptroller Glenn Hegar says.
"Growth in state sales tax revenue was led by receipts from the construction, information services and restaurant sectors," Hegar said.
In a statement released Friday, the comptroller's office said the majority of December sales tax revenue is based on sales made in November and remitted to the agency in December.
Total sales tax revenue for the three months ending in December 2019 was up 6.0 percent compared to the same period a year ago.
Sales tax is the largest source of state funding for the state budget, accounting for 57 percent of all tax collections.

title: Dec. 1 could go into the history books as DFW Airport’s busiest day ever
summary:
The rush to get home after this year’s Thanksgiving holiday could make Dec. 1 the busiest travel day in the history of DFW International Airport and cause big lines at Dallas Love Field.
Dec. 1 should mark the peak of what is expected to be a record holiday travel season, and the most passengers DFW Airport and Dallas Love Field have ever seen.
At Dallas Love Field, the Sunday before Thanksgiving was the busiest travel day of the season in 2018 with 20,675 passengers arriving alone.
Last year at DFW Airport, TSA security line wait times were about 17 minutes on the Sunday following Thanksgiving, the busiest day of the week with 66,714 passengers.
Last year’s busiest holiday travel day at DFW Airport was Thursday, Dec. 27, according to TSA statistics.

title: Hank Steinbrenner, Yankees Co-Owner, Dead at 63
summary:
Hank Steinbrenner, the oldest son of George Steinbrenner and one of the four siblings who own the controlling shares of the New York Yankees, died Tuesday at age 63.
George Steinbrenner died in July 2010 and wife Joan died in December 2018.
A rock fan, Hank Steinbrenner kept a Fender Stratocaster guitar on the floor near the door of his office at the Yankees’ spring training ballpark.
He coordinated a partnership with Gwynn Racing in 2000 to field a Gwynn/Steinbrenner Yankees dragster on the National Hot Rod Association tour and with son George Michael Steinbrenner IV formed Steinbrenner Racing in 2016.
The group competed on the Indy Lights developmental circuit in 2017-18, then partnered to form Harding Steinbrenner Racing which started on the IndyCar circuit in 2019.

Risks to Texas Prosperity in 2020 and Beyond
summary:
The Texas economy is probably strong enough to shake off some potential shocks—just as it did with the 2014 plunge in oil prices.
It’s not hard, though, to envision scenarios that would set Texas’ economy reeling.
Texas needs more of these workers, especially the highly skilled, and Trump’s across-the-board hostility to immigrants threatens to weaken the state’s economy.
The Bottom LineSome of the threats to Texas’ economy may not amount to much as events move forward, and others might prove more ominous than they appear today.
None of the risks are immediate, and the Texas and DFW economies are likely to continue growing in 2020, perhaps at a slightly slower pace.

title: DFW Airport will shatter passenger records in 2019, but it’s racking up more flight delays, too
